response:
Round 1 — Choose car. Fuel cost €54 for the trip (cheaper than €60). I own a car and prefer the convenience and door-to-door travel when it’s also cheaper.

Round 2 — Choose car. Fuel cost €60 equals the train fare. I’d likely drive here for flexibility (timing, luggage) unless I wanted to avoid driving that day; at parity I lean to the car.

Round 3 — Choose train. Fuel €66 > train €60, so the train saves money. I’d take the train to cut costs and avoid extra wear on the car.

Round 4 — Choose train. Fuel €72 is noticeably more expensive; the train is cheaper and easier given rising fuel costs.

Round 5 — Choose train. Fuel €78 — I’d switch to the train to save money and because the price difference is significant.

Round 6 — Choose train. Fuel €84 — still much more than €60, so train makes more financial sense.

Round 7 — Choose train. Fuel €90 — same reasoning: cost savings and less stress driving.

Round 8 — Choose train. Fuel €94 — I’d take the train; the car trip is substantially more expensive.

Round 9 — Choose train. Fuel €100 — by now it’s clearly cheaper to travel by train and avoid high fuel costs and extra wear on the car.

Round 1 — Fuel €54 vs Train €60: Choose car. Fuel is cheaper for the trip and I value the door-to-door convenience and carrying any luggage; since it’s cheaper, I’d drive.

Round 2 — Fuel €60 vs Train €60: Choose car. Costs are equal, but owning a car and wanting flexibility (timing, door-to-door, no transfers) tips me to drive.

Round 3 — Fuel €66 vs Train €60: Choose train. Train is cheaper and I’d prefer not to pay extra for petrol; also I can relax/ work on the train.

Round 4 — Fuel €72 vs Train €60: Choose train. Higher fuel cost makes the train clearly the better economic choice, and it’s more relaxing.

Round 5 — Fuel €78 vs Train €60: Choose train. Substantially more expensive to drive; I’d take the train.

Round 6 — Fuel €84 vs Train €60: Choose train. Too costly to drive compared with the train fare.

Round 7 — Fuel €90 vs Train €60: Choose train. Train saves a lot of money; I’d take it.

Round 8 — Fuel €94 vs Train €60: Choose train. Driving is much more expensive; I’d go by train.

Round 9 — Fuel €100 vs Train €60: Choose train. No question — the train is far cheaper and preferable given the cost difference.

Round 1 — Fuel €54 vs Train €60
Choice: Car.
Why: Fuel is cheaper by €6 and I own a car, so for a small price advantage I’d drive for the convenience (door-to-door, flexibility), even though the car emits ~75 kg CO₂.

Round 2 — Fuel €60 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Same price, so I prefer the train because it emits almost no CO₂ and I can relax/read on the way rather than drive.

Round 3 — Fuel €66 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Train is €6 cheaper and much better on emissions, so I’d take the train.

Round 4 — Fuel €72 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Train is clearly cheaper and far less polluting; I wouldn’t pay the extra for the car.

Round 5 — Fuel €78 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Big price gap plus low emissions makes the train the obvious choice.

Round 6 — Fuel €84 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Even more expensive to drive; environmental and cost reasons push me to the train.

Round 7 — Fuel €90 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: No contest — train is much cheaper and cleaner.

Round 8 — Fuel €94 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Cost and emissions strongly favor the train.

Round 9 — Fuel €100 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Driving is far more expensive and produces the ~75 kg CO₂, so I’d definitely take the train.

Round 1 — Fuel €54 vs Train €60: Choose car.
Reason: The car is noticeably cheaper (€6 saved). I own a car and value the flexibility/comfort for this trip, so I’d drive despite the CO₂, though I’m aware it emits 75 kg.

Round 2 — Fuel €60 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Same out‑of‑pocket cost, and since the car emits a lot of CO₂ while the train is almost emission‑free, I’d take the train for the environmental benefit.

Round 3 — Fuel €66 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Train is cheaper and cleaner; no reason to drive when it costs more and produces 75 kg CO₂.

Round 4 — Fuel €72 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Fuel is considerably more expensive and emissions are high, so train wins on both cost and environmental grounds.

Round 5 — Fuel €78 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Bigger price gap and the train has almost no emissions — clear choice for me.

Round 6 — Fuel €84 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Same as above: much cheaper and far lower CO₂ impact.

Round 7 — Fuel €90 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Driving is significantly more expensive and worse for the climate, so I’d take the train.

Round 8 — Fuel €94 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Strong cost and environmental incentives to choose the train.

Round 9 — Fuel €100 vs Train €60: Choose train.
Reason: Very large price difference and the train’s near‑zero emissions make it the clear option.
